授業目的: The purpose of this course is to introduce the diplomatic history of prewar U.S.-Japan relations from the arrival of Perry to the fateful termination of the bilateral relationship with the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941. In order to accomplish this, the foreign polices of both countries will be examined, with particular focus in the area of diplomacy, economics, and security. Japan's resistance to the established world order and the path to Pearl Harbor will be prominent themes of the course, and students will also be exposed to basic concepts of diplomatic history. Upon completion of this course, students will have gained a deeper and much richer insight into Japanese diplomacy of the Meiji, Taisho, and pre-1941 Showa periods.
到達目標: The learning goals of this course is to  understand the key concepts and events in prewar Japanese diplomatic history from the arrival of Perry to the fateful decision to go to war in December 1941. Focus will be placed  on the pivotal decade of the 1930s with particular focus in the area of diplomacy, economics, and security. Japan's challenge to the established world order and the road to Pearl Harbor will be the prominent themes of the course. Students will also be exposed to basic concepts of military history. Upon completion of this course, students will have gained a deeper and much richer insight into Japan's foreign policy decision making process.
